prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: Breach of Implied Provisions of a Contract

para.paratext: If there are no express provisions in a contract, contractual obligations may, in some circumstances, be implied against a party to a contract.[1]
In Faccenda Chicken Ltd. v. Fowler,[2] the English Court of Appeal held that information may fit within one of three categories:
information which is trivial or easily accessible from public sources and is not confidential;
information which is confidential, but which becomes part of the servant's skill and knowledge; or
confidential business information which cannot be lawfully used for anyone's benefit but that of the party who imparted the information in confidence.[3]

Information which falls into the first category is not considered confidential business information and may therefore be disclosed without fear of repercussion. Information which falls into the second category cannot be disclosed during the term of the employment contract. However, it may be disclosed when the employment relationship ends because it has become “skill and knowledge” of the employee and cannot be separated from the general knowledge of the employee. Information falling into the third category cannot be disclosed either during or after the term of the employment contract.[4]

The courts will protect confidential business information which falls into the third category regardless of whether there is an express provision in the contract. In order to determine whether information falls within an implied term of a contract, it is necessary to consider the following factors:

the nature of the employment or business. In certain occupations and commercial fields, confidential information is frequently divulged. In such a case, the employee would be expected to realize the confidentiality of the information to a greater extent than if the employee were only occasionally exposed to confidential business information;
whether one party to the agreement impressed upon the other party the importance of maintaining the confidentiality of the information; and
whether the relevant information can be easily isolated from other information.[5]
These factors are used as a guide in determining how much information will be covered by implied contractual terms.
The kinds of duties which may form the basis for a breach of an implied contract include:
the duty not to compete with the employer for the duration of the contract, within or outside working hours;
the duty not to make plans to compete with the employer after leaving, or to enable another person to do so;
the duty not to disclose or use the employer's or a competing business's confidential business information; and
the duty to disclose to the employer information which may be of use.[6]
In contracts arising between businesses, the courts will usually only enforce the obligation not to use confidential information which belongs to another and was imparted in confidence.[7]

Where there is an express contract which does not include a restrictive covenant, the court may rely on the doctrine of rectification in order to grant an injunction to prevent an employee from competing with the former employer.[8]
